documents.document: @JosieLong I know what you mean! We (in Ireland) had nothing to do with it, no vote & it's such a headache for us!
@rickoshea I got it for Christmas but haven't read it yet. He's a wonderful writer.
@rickoshea @rickoshea Have you read the Costa Prize winning (yay!) Days Without End by our own Sebastian Barry yet? #askrickanything
@Damienlanesun Thank you so much! I'm very grateful indeed!
@UniRdg_SpecColl Great blog post! I wrote a profile of George Egerton: https://t.co/649Atqes4W & The Yellow Book: https://t.co/lxAKWWoAXt
@Damienlanesun Any help VERY gratefully received! :)
@Damienlanesun Thanks! That's all I have. Comes from burial record (Norwood Cemetery, London) Mary Collis Nesbit. Died in France 30/11/1871
Trying to understand an address in France 'La Haute Motte, Chateau Neuf' ( from a death cert 1871). Anyone? Would be grateful for any help
@victorianclare Yes! Next to impossible. I'm desperately seeking refuge in the 1880s but keep popping back to the present.

Fascinating! Love Star Trek mention. Futility of charity echoed in The Woman's World & Wilde's The Happy Prince tooâ€¦ https://t.co/jidwzvLqhS

That's really interesting thanks @berndools! I know very little about his work. https://t.co/4jYbrYVOfq
@urchinette Yes not someone you'd want to hang out with by the sounds of him! I'd say your ancestors were happy to see the back of him!
@urchinette Pierce Murphy, the 'comfortable Co. Louth farmer'. He's in O'Donoghue's Life of too: https://t.co/QJk03NVRp7

@barbarascully Ya would not! Several women in my class had never been before & they were the most brilliant of all. Did short access course.
@barbarascully GO! It's brilliant & you'd love it! I went in my late 40s & met the best people & wasn't just mum. MA maybe?
@HistoryNeedsYou Excellent tweet. Solidarity not artificial division is what's needed now & always.
